posts.body:
Agnes Hotot

Joane Agnes Hotot (b. 1395) was an English noblewoman and heiress during the Middle Ages (Medieval Times). She took her father’s place in a duel after he fell ill and beat her opponent in a lance fight. After the duel, she let down her hair to prove she was a woman–a crest of a woman in a war helmet was created in her honor soon after.

posts.body:
Elba Lightfoot

An African-American artist, Elba Lightfoot (born 1910) was a Harlem painter.

Lightfoot founded the Harlem Artists Guild and was a respected member of the social circle of Black artists, working with notable people like Charles Alston, Augusta Savage, and Arthur Schomburg.

Her most notable works were her murals–Lightfoot painted murals at Harlem Hospital as part of a Works Progress Administration art program.

posts.body:
dailyhistoryposts:

Mary Ann Bugg

One of only a couple notable female bushrangers, Mary Ann Bugg (1834-1905) was an Aboriginal woman of the Worimi people.

Born to a Worimi mother and a convict father from Essex, England, Mary Ann was sent to Sydney to be educated.

Bugg worked with her lover, Frederick Ward (“Captain Thunderbolt”), whom she helped escape Cockatoo Island. Bushrangers were those who lived in the bush and made a living by robbery, similar to British highwaymen or American Wild West outlaws. Bushranging lasted for over a century, having significant influence and popularity today. Native-born bushrangers were among some of the first Australian nationalists and folk heroes.

Bugg was often described as a ‘young man’ as she wore trousers and rode astride. She was in charge of intelligence gathering, keeping camp, and helping organize robberies. She was apprehended by the police three times, though at least two were overturned.

posts.summary:
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endonym_and_exonym

Which would referring to all places, peoples, and languages exclusively by...
posts.question:
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endonym_and_exonym


Which would referring to all places, peoples, and languages exclusively by their endonym be?

A. Actively helpful/a sign of respect

B. Useless but not hurting anyone or anything

C. Actively harmful/disrespectful


I wanna make sure I'm being respectful of (people from) other cultures and nations.
posts.answer:
Great question! If anyone else wants to add their perspective to this, I’d love to hear it.

I think using endonyms is more respectful and also more correct, and prefer them as a default.

However, it’s not 100% clear-cut, and is complicated by the fact that

1. For many indigenous names, the exonym is better recognized and is often the legal name
2. Some people, especially historical figures, referred to themselves as their endonym
3. Many places or languages have multiple endonyms because multiple groups are from them.

As an example, one of the groups indigenous to what is now the southeastern United States are legally and commonly referred to by their exonym, the Cherokee. Their endonym is usually Aniyunwiya, but it is also Anigiduwagi and sometimes Tsalagi. One notable member of this group, Redbird Smith (1850-1918), refers to himself and his people as Cherokee in recorded quotes.

My goal is to be accurate, accessible, and respectful. In talking about Redbird Smith, I would most likely call the group the Aniyunwiya (but put Cherokee in parenthesis) and I would not edit direct quotes from Smith.

posts.body:
Ella Josephine Baker

One of the most important organizers for the Civil Rights Movement, Ella Josephine Baker (1903-1986) worked for five decades all over the country.

Baker was born in Virginia but raised in North Carolina after a violent attack on Black workers in her town of birth, and she grew up hearing her grandmother’s stories about enslavement.

Baker attended Shaw University and was valedictorian of her class. In the 1930s, she worked as an editorial assistant at the Negro National News and was the national director of the Young Negroes Cooperative League. She also founded the Negro History Club at the Harlem Library.

In 1938, Baker began working with the NAACP. She traveled throughout the country, especially in the South, recruiting and raising money. Influenced by anarchist ideals, Baker pushed for a decentralized leadership structure and grassroots-level organization. Baker emphasized treating all people with respect and was able to convince a great many women, young people, and rural workers of their commonality with the New York City, seemingly elite, NAACP organization.

Baker helped form the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC) to work with the momentum of the Montgomery bus boycott. Baker helped organize the Crusade for Citizenship, a voter registration campaign. Then she founded the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, the SNCC, one of the most important civil rights groups in US history.

This is a sampling of Baker’s work–her dedication to decentralized pro-Black activism led to the creation and success of multiple important activist groups.

posts.body:
Claudia Jones

A Trinidad and Tobago-born journalist, feminist, and Black Nationalist, Claudia Jones (1915-1964) was one of the most important Black Communists of the 20th century.

Born in Trinidad (then a British colony) and raised in Harlem from age eight, Claudia Jones (born Claudia Vera Cumberbatch, she changed it for anonymity) was a bright student raised by a single father in a poor family. An early bought with tuberculosis damaged her lungs, which would result in hospital stays throughout her life.

Jones joined the Young Communist League USA in 1936 to support the Scottsboro Boys and oppose the Italian invasion of Ethiopia. An excellent writer and journalist, she would join the editorial staff of the Daily Worker and write for other Communist papers.

Politically, Jones focused on anti-imperialism, working-class leadership, and increasing the involvement of women in the Communist Party. Her best-known piece of writing (which you can read here), “An End to the Neglect of the Problems of the Negro Woman!” would show a deep understanding of what Kimberlé Crenshaw would later term ‘intersectionality’.

Throughout her life, Jones would be arrested at least four times, convicted of “un-American activities”, and deported. She moved to London when she was denied entry into Trinidad and Tobago, whereupon she immediately joined the Community Party of Great Britain and continued her activism.

Claudia Jones also founded the Notting Hill Carnival, the second-largest annual carnival in the world.

posts.body:
Langston Hughes

James Mercer Langston Hughes (1901-1967) was a Black jazz poet, activist, and a leader of the Harlem Renaissance.

Hughes was born in Joplin, Missouri and grew up moving between small Midwest towns before moving the New York City. He worked aboard a ship and travelled to West Africa and Europe, before returning to the States to receive his bachelor’s degree from Lincoln University.

As a poet, Hughes’ works were immensely popular in his lifetime. He was an early innovator in jazz poetry, a form of poetry that incorporated jazz and blues rhythms into poetry, which was a hallmark of the Harlem Renaissance.

Politically, Hughes was drawn to Communism, and travelled to the USSR and China. He supported Communist-affiliated initiatives and organizations, but never joined the Communist party. Nevertheless, it was certainly the political stance he felt the most affinity for.

Hughes never married, nor is there any evidence he was romantically or sexually interested in any women in his life. Academics and biographers debate over the specifics–he was almost certainly gay, but it’s likely he was asexual as well. Some of his stories discuss the emotional impact of being an effeminate child, and he had a number of unpublished love poems that were likely intended for a man. However, there is less evidence of sexual, rather than romantic desire, and the historical records shows that other queer Black poets (Alain Locke and Countee Cullen) were interested in Hughes, but never slept with him.

This is a case where we cannot prescribe with certainty prescribe an identity onto a historical figure. Unlike other figures in the Harlem Renaissance (including Hughes’ own social circle, who sometimes took him to drag clubs), Hughes never came out or had a single confirmed partner. His writings were more strongly romantic, devoid of the sexual aspect that was common for gay writings of the period. But at the end of the day, we do not know exactly how Hughes described himself then, and we certainly cannot know how he would describe himself if he were alive today.

tags: we're getting spicy with this one
posts.body:
Angela Davis

A scholar, activist, and philosopher, Angela Davis (born 1944) is a powerful and influential, but also often criticized public figure. She has had a place in many notable groups of people, including the National Women’s Hall of Fame, the Time’s list of the 100 most influential people in the world, and the FBI’s Ten Most Wanted Fugitive List.

Davis was born in Birmingham, Alabama, in a neighborhood that had been bombed in an attempt to drive-out the Black people who lived there. She attended a segregated school until she was able to transfer to an integrated high school in New York City. From a young age, she was educated and influenced by communists. Academically, she was particularly interested in the works of the Existentialist Jean-Paul Sartre.

It is beyond the scope to detail everything she has done–Davis is an incredibly accomplished woman–so as a brief rundown of a few of her more notable actions, she

  1. Participated in the radical Socialist German Student Union in East Germany
  2. Joined the Black Panther Party
  3. Joined the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee
  4. Joined the Che-Lumumba Club
  5. Earned a PhD
  6. Began teaching, was fired for being a Communist, was rehired, was refired
  7. Was declared a terrorist and on the FBI’s Ten Most Wanted Fugitive List (only the third woman to be so listed)
  8. Was declared not guilty by an all-White jury (after an international backlash)
  9. Resumed teaching, but secretly, despite being officially hired? Her students were sworn to secrecy but it was an actual class.

Davis is a lesbian; she lives with her partner, fellow professor, Gina Dent.

  3. Joined the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee
  4. Joined the Che-Lumumba Club
  5. Earned a PhD
  6. Began teaching, was fired for being a Communist, was rehired, was refired
  7. Was declared a terrorist and on the FBI’s Ten Most Wanted Fugitive List (only the third woman to be so listed)
  8. Was declared not guilty by an all-White jury (after an international backlash)
  9. Resumed teaching, but secretly, despite being officially hired? Her students were sworn to secrecy but it was an actual class.

Davis is a lesbian; she lives with her partner, fellow professor, Gina Dent.

posts.body:
Fannie Lou Hamer


Fannie Lou Hamer (1917-1977) was a leader in the Civil Rights Movement and a women’s rights activist.

Hamer was born in Montgomery County, Mississippi, one of 20 children to farmers. Her family was the subject of racist attacks, and Hamer started working as a sharecropper at age 6. At 12, she left school to support her parents, despite having polio.

In 1962, Hamer and 17 others were denied the right to vote due to failing a literacy test (she was perfectly literate–in fact, Hamer was the recordkeeper on the plantation she had worked on. Nevertheless, she would be patronized by Black and White activists alike for her lack of a formal education). She was fired and continued to try to pass the literacy test on her third try, but still couldn’t vote as she had no poll tax receipts.

Hamer began to focus on her activism, including with the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. Her efforts focused on registering Black people, especially Black women, to vote.

In 1963, Hamer and many others were arrested while traveling to a conference in South Carolina. While arrested, they faced serious police brutality (which will not be detailed here, but the information is available). She never fully recovered, physically or psychologically.

Hamer was, among her many accomplishments, a co-founder of the National Women’s Political Caucus, a national party delegate to the Freedom 1964 Democratic National Convention, and a pioneer of the Freedom Farm Cooperative (an agricultural cooperative and economic development program). In 1971, Hamer co-founded the National Women’s Political Caucus.

Hamer was a famous and popular speaker. Her oratory style was less polished than people she shared a stage with, but she was able to connect to her audience because of it. Her most famous speech, “I’m Sick and Tired of Being Sick and Tired”, can be read in its entirety here. It details her experience of racism, violence, police brutality, and sexual harassment.

posts.body:
Zephyr Wright

The White House kitchen, the workplace of some of the finest chefs in the United States, has been a place of Black excellence since the beginning. Zephyr Wright (1915-1988) was the personal chef for President Lyndon Johnson and a notably Civil Rights activist–her experiences were influential in the passing of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

Wright grew up in Marshall, Texas, and was inspired to join the Civil Rights Movement from a young age. In 1942, she was hired as a cook for Lady Bird and Lyndon Johnson (then a representative).

Despite her culinary excellence and the respect she earned, Wright lived in a segregated world. She was kept out of hotels, restaurants, and bathrooms. She outright refused to return to Texas with the Johnsons.

As president, Johnson often asked Wright’s opinion on his political actions, including the appointment of Thurgood Marshall, the first Black person to the Supreme Court. She advocated for fair wages for Black workers in the White House and bravely told stories of her life of discrimination, part of why Johnson pushed so hard on Civil Rights legislation.

As both a chef and an activist, Zephyr Wright changed the world. She witnessed the signing of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and, afterward, received the pen used to sign it from Johnson, who said “You deserve this more than anyone else.” Her cooking was world-renown by politicians and dignitaries, and she would receive fanmail for her cooking long after her retirement. The New York Times has called Wright one of “6 Black Chefs Who Changed the History of Food”.

Check out, and maybe try making, some of her recipes!

1. Pedernales River Chili (here mistakenly attributed to Lady Bird)

2. Shrimp Curry a la Zephyr Wright
